datafield.subfield: Office of Human Resources and Affirmative Action.
Office of Human Resources and Affirmative Action (University of Michigan) records,

In 1945 Personnel Office was founded to develop and implement personnel policies and deal with issues of hiring, firing, promotion, tenure, remuneration, and contract negotiations. The Affirmative Action Office was created in 1972 to monitor the University's enforcement of federal and state affirmative action legislation, such as Title IX, Equal Employment Opportunity Act, and Age Descrimination in Employment Act, and reporting the University's compliance to the federal and state governments. This office was also responsible for ensuring fair and equitable hiring practices within the University. In 1994, the two offices were combined and reorganized to form the Office of Human Resources and Affirmative Action.

Records include topical files regarding grievance policies and procedures, correspondence and compliance reports for Title IX, Executive Order 11246, Title IV, and other anti-discriminatory legislation. Contains correspondence and reports regarding incidents of racism on campus and the University's efforts to eradicate such behavior. Also includes correspondence between the Affirmative Action office and the schools and colleges regarding policy issues of faculty and staff hiring and firing, retention of women and minorities, retirements, and reductions-in-force. Also contains correspondence and testimony and statistics presented at state hearings regarding recruitment and retention of minority students. These records document this office's work with women's groups including the Academic Women's Caucus, the Center for Continuing Education of Women, the Commission for Women, and the Women's Information Group. Also includes personnel files of the various schools and colleges, as well as visual materials.
